importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the plane crash, which occurred on September 18, 2025, marks the incident that led to the NTSB investigation and public attention regarding aviation safety and communication protocols.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The time period from September 18 to October 20, 2025, encompasses the crash, the investigation by the NTSB, and the public release of the preliminary findings.

keyTakeAways: Brett James, a Grammy-winning songwriter known for collaborations with Taylor Swift, Bon Jovi, and Keith Urban, died in a plane crash on September 18, 2025, while attempting a visual approach to runway 7 at Franklin, North Carolina.
The National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) reported that the plane, a Cirrus SR22T, entered a 'tightening spiral' before crashing, with no mechanical issues found in the wreckage.
James had requested a visual approach to runway 7, which was approved by air traffic control, but failed to tune to the common traffic advisory frequency (CTAF), leading to a loss of communication.
The controller attempted to alert James that he had not changed the radio frequency, but there were no further communications.
The plane flew over the runway, executed a left turn, descended, and then entered a spiral before crashing, killing all three people on board.
James was a major figure in country music, notably co-writing 'Out Last Night' for Kenny Chesney and 'Jesus, Take the Wheel' for Carrie Underwood, which helped launch her career.

namedEntities.name: Brett James
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Grammy-winning songwriter and music industry collaborator
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Brett James is relevant to the world outside of the article because of his significant contributions to country music, including co-writing hit songs for major artists like Carrie Underwood and Kenny Chesney, making him a widely recognized and influential figure in the music industry.

namedEntities.name: National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A U.S. government agency responsible for investigating transportation accidents
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The NTSB is relevant because it conducted and released a preliminary report on the crash, providing official insight into the cause of the incident and highlighting aviation safety issues.

namedEntities.name: Cirrus SR22T
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A single-engine, general aviation aircraft model
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Cirrus SR22T is relevant because it was the specific plane involved in the crash, and its flight characteristics were key to understanding the nature of the spiral and crash.

namedEntities.name: Franklin, North Carolina
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A location in North Carolina where the crash occurred
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Franklin, North Carolina, is relevant as the geographic location of the crash site, which is approximately 270 miles southeast of Nashville.

namedEntities.name: Runway 7
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A designated runway at the airport in Franklin, North Carolina
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Runway 7 was the intended landing point for the flight, and the failure to properly execute a visual approach to this runway was central to the incident.

namedEntities.name: Common Traffic Advisory Frequency (CTAF)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A radio frequency used by pilots to report location and intentions when no tower is present
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The failure to tune to CTAF was a critical error that led to the loss of communication between the pilot and air traffic control, contributing directly to the crash.

namedEntities.name: Carrie Underwood
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A country music singer and former winner of 'American Idol'
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Carrie Underwood is relevant because her debut album featured a song co-written by Brett James, which helped launch her career and established James as a key music industry figure.

namedEntities.name: Kenny Chesney
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Kenny Chesney is relevant because Brett James co-wrote 'Out Last Night' for him, highlighting James’ reputation as a top-tier songwriter in the country music industry.

namedEntities.name: Taylor Swift
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A globally renowned pop and country music artist
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Taylor Swift is relevant because Brett James has worked with her, showcasing his prominence and influence in high-profile music collaborations.

namedEntities.name: Bon Jovi
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Bon Jovi is relevant because Brett James has collaborated with the band, emphasizing his broad reach across music genres.

namedEntities.name: Keith Urban

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Keith Urban is relevant because Brett James has collaborated with him, further underscoring his status as a sought-after songwriter in country music.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The National Transportation Safety Board reported that Grammy-winning songwriter Brett James, 57, died in a plane crash on September 18, 2025, while flying a Cirrus SR22T to Franklin, North Carolina. The aircraft entered a 'tightening spiral' after James failed to tune to the common traffic advisory frequency (CTAF), despite air traffic control's instructions. He had requested a visual approach to runway 7, but did not change the radio frequency, resulting in lost communication. The NTSB found no mechanical issues in the plane, and the incident highlights critical issues in pilot-traffic control communication. Brett James was a major figure in country music, known for co-writing hits for artists such as Carrie Underwood, Kenny Chesney, Taylor Swift, Bon Jovi, and Keith Urban.
title: Songwriter Brett James’ plane enters a 'tightening spiral' before crashing, NTSB says
